a small, old star that is not very hot
to come or go upwards; to reach a higher level or position

examples.x: The curtain rose to reveal an empty stage.
Smoke was rising from the chimney.
The river has risen by several metres.
A stream of bubbles rose to the surface.
The flood waters were rising fast.

senses.definition: to increase in amount or number increased

examples.x: Prices are still rising.
rising fuel bills
The price of gas rose.
Gas rose in price.
The shares have risen in value.
Global temperatures could rise three degrees or more.
Unemployment rose by 3 per cent.
Interest rates rose to a six-year high.
to rise sharply/dramatically/rapidly/steeply
to rise steadily/slightly
We are seeing a rising tide of online crime (= a large increase in it).

senses.definition: when the sun, moon, etc. rises, it appears above the horizon rises

examples.x: The sun rises in the east.
It was almost dark and the moon was just rising.

senses.definition: to become more successful, important, powerful, etc.

examples.x: a rising young politician
He rose to prominence in the 90s.
to rise to fame/power
You could rise to the top if you work hard.
He rose to the rank of general.
She has risen to a position of great responsibility.
She rose through the ranks to become managing director.

senses.definition: to get up from a lying, sitting or kneeling position stand

examples.x: He was accustomed to rising (= getting out of bed) early.
They rose from the table.
She rose to her feet.

senses.definition: to end a meeting

examples.x: The House (= members of the House of Commons) rose at 10 p.m.

senses.definition: if a sound rises, it becomes louder and higher rises

examples.x: Her voice rose angrily.

senses.definition: if the wind rises, it begins to blow more strongly rises

examples.x: The wind is rising—I think there's a storm coming.

senses.definition: if a feeling rises inside you, it begins and gets stronger rises

examples.x: He felt anger rising inside him.
Her spirits rose (= she felt happier) at the news.

senses.definition: if your colour rises, your face becomes pink or red because you are embarrassed rises
if hair rises, it stands up instead of lying flat rises

examples.x: The hair on the back of my neck rose when I heard the scream.

senses.definition: to begin to fight against your government or leader or against a foreign army

examples.x: The peasants rose in revolt.
He called on the people to rise up against the invaders.

senses.definition: to be able to be seen above everything that is around

examples.x: Mountains rose in the distance.

senses.definition: if land rises, it slopes upwards rises

examples.x: The ground rose steeply all around.
Behind the house the ground rises steeply to the north.

senses.definition: a river rises where it begins to flow rises

examples.x: The Thames rises in the Cotswold hills.

senses.definition: when bread, cakes, etc. rise, they become larger and rounder because of the action of yeast or baking powder rise
to come to life again

examples.x: to rise from the dead
Can a new party rise from the ashes of the old one?

senses.definition: a spacecraft in the shape of a tube that is driven by a stream of gases let out behind it when fuel is burned inside

examples.x: a space rocket
The rocket was launched in 2007.
The idea took off like a rocket (= it immediately became popular).

senses.definition: a missile (= a weapon that travels through the air) that carries a bomb and is driven by a stream of burning gases

examples.x: a rocket attack
A rocket smashed into the side of the building.

senses.definition: a firework that goes high into the air and then explodes with coloured lights
a plant with long green leaves that have a strong taste and are eaten raw in salads
the action of an object moving in a circle around a central fixed point

examples.x: the daily rotation of the earth on its axis
the earth's rotation around the sun

senses.definition: one complete movement in a circle around a fixed point

examples.x: This switch controls the number of rotations per minute.

senses.definition: the act of regularly changing the thing that is being used in a particular situation, or of changing the person who does a particular job

examples.x: crop rotation/the rotation of crops (= changing the crop that is grown on an area of land in order to protect the soil)
job rotation (= the practice of regularly changing the job that a particular person does so that they become experienced in different areas)
Wheat, maize and sugar beet are planted in rotation.
The committee is chaired by all the members in rotation.

senses.definition: an electronic device that is sent into space and moves around the earth or another planet. It is used for communicating by radio, television, etc. and for gathering information. watch

examples.x: a weather/communications/spy satellite
The interview came live by satellite from Hollywood.
They could track the tagged sea turtles by satellite.
The information was sent via a satellite link.
satellite television/TV/radio (= broadcast using a satellite)
a satellite broadcast/channel/picture
The use of satellite phones meant that journalists could report directly from the arena of the battlefront.
My car was fitted with a satellite navigation system.
The software enables the user to set up a satellite communications link.
They have successfully launched satellites into orbit.

senses.definition: a natural object that moves around a larger natural object in space

examples.x: The moon is a satellite of earth.

senses.definition: a town, a country or an organization that is controlled by and depends on another larger or more powerful one

examples.x: Following the Second World War it became a satellite state of the Soviet Union.

senses.definition: a large planet in the solar system that has rings around it and is 6th in order of distance from the sun

a US rocket used in the 1960s and 1970s to send spacecraft and satellites into space. The original Saturn was developed in 1958 by Wernher von Braun, and it had two rockets used in sequence. Saturn 5 had three rockets and carried 12 million US gallons /45.6 million litres of fuel. It was used for the Apollo program to send men to the moon.
a popular make of small US car that is cheap to run, produced by General Motors since 1990
to produce or reflect light; to be bright shine

examples.x: The sun shone brightly in a cloudless sky.
A light was shining in the distance.
The dark polished wood shone like glass.
The stars were shining and the moon was bright.
The hot desert sun shone down relentlessly.
the beauty of the moon shining on the waves
Her eyes were shining with excitement.
Excitement was shining in her eyes.

senses.definition: to aim or point the light of a lamp, etc. in a particular direction

examples.x: He shone the flashlight around the cellar.
The watchman shone his torch at us.
The doctor shone the light in my eyes several times.
Campaigners are shining a spotlight on the world's diminishing natural resources.

senses.definition: to polish something; to make something smooth and bright

examples.x: He shined shoes and sold newspapers to make money.

senses.definition: to show that you are very good at something

examples.x: He failed to shine academically but he was very good at sports.
She has set a shining example of loyal service over four decades.
These qualities shine forth in all that he produced.

senses.definition: a small meteor (= a piece of rock in outer space) that travels very fast and burns with a bright light as it enters the earth’s atmosphere
of or connected with the sun

examples.x: solar radiation
a solar eclipse
solar wind
the solar cycle

senses.definition: using the sun’s energy cause/​contribute to

examples.x: solar heating
a satellite telephone with solar-powered batteries

senses.definition: the sun and all the planets that move around it
any group of planets that all move around the same star

examples.x: We don’t know how many solar systems there are in each galaxy.

senses.definition: the time it takes the earth to go around the sun once, approximately 365¼ days
a group of stars in the shape of a cross that can be seen from the southern hemisphere
bands of coloured light that are sometimes seen in the sky at night in the most southern countries of the world
the area outside the earth’s atmosphere where all the other planets and stars are

examples.x: Valentina Tereshkova was the first woman in space.
the possibility of visitors from outer space
space exploration/travel
a space flight/mission
the US space program

senses.definition: an area or a place that is empty

examples.x: an empty space
a large/small/narrow/wide space
a space two metres by three metres
He reversed out of the parking space.
We were crowded together in a confined space.
They cram hundreds of animals into a tiny space.
Put it in the space between the table and the wall.
I'll clear a space for your books.
The sculpture occupies a space in the centre of the campus.

senses.definition: an amount of an area or of a place that is empty or that is available for use

examples.x: We have 50  000 square metres of floor space.
Different brands compete for shelf space.
Houses were built close together with almost no empty space between them.
We must make good use of the available space.
That desk takes up too much space.
Traffic tends to expand to fill the space available.
There is very little storage space in the department.
Arrive early because space is limited.
This creates space for a bigger table.
Can we make space for one more person?
disk/memory space (= on a computer or device)

senses.definition: a place, especially a room or a building, that can be used for a particular purpose

examples.x: The venue is a great space for music.
various gallery and exhibition spaces
to rent/lease (a) space
He was sharing office space with a lawyer.
The business began to occupy more space.

senses.definition: the quality of being large and empty, allowing you to move freely

examples.x: The room has been furnished and decorated to give a feeling of space.
We're enjoying the space here after living in a small flat.

senses.definition: a large area of land that has no buildings on it land

examples.x: the wide open spaces of the Canadian prairies
protection for our parks and other green spaces
It's a city with fine buildings and plenty of open space.
Green space is important in the urban environment.

senses.definition: a period of time

examples.x: Leave a space of two weeks between appointments.
Forty-four people died in the space of five days.
They had achieved a lot in a short space of time.

senses.definition: the part of a line, page or document that is empty

examples.x: Don't waste space by leaving a wide margin.
There was not enough space to print all the letters we received.
Leave a space after the comma.

senses.definition: the freedom and the time to think or do what you want to

examples.x: She was upset and needed space.
You have to give teenagers plenty of space.

senses.definition: the whole area in which all things exist and move

examples.x: It is quite possible that space and time are finite.
the fabric of space and time

senses.definition: an area of business in which a person or an organization operates

examples.x: His investments have focused on the healthcare space.
Right now, the team is primarily at work on products within the mobile space.

senses.definition: a vehicle that travels in space

examples.x: An unmanned Chinese spacecraft has returned safely to Earth.
They plan to send a spacecraft to the moon.
a spacecraft orbiting the earth

senses.definition: a man who travels into space; an astronaut
(in stories) a creature that visits the earth from another planet
a spacecraft without people on board that obtains information and sends it back to earth
a vehicle that travels in space, carrying people
a spacecraft designed to make repeated journeys, for example between the earth and a space station
a large structure that is sent into space and remains above the earth as a base for people working and travelling in space
a special suit that covers the whole body and has a supply of air, allowing somebody to survive and move around in space
the universe considered as a continuum with four measurements—length, width, depth and time—inside which any event or physical object is located
a period of time that an astronaut spends in space outside a spacecraft
a woman who travels into space; an astronaut
a satellite of the type that was put into space by the Soviet Union
a large ball of burning gas in space that we see as a point of light in the sky at night

examples.x: There was a big moon and hundreds of stars were shining overhead.
Sirius is the brightest star in the sky.
We camped out under the stars.

senses.definition: an object, a decoration, a mark, etc., usually with five or six points, whose shape represents a star

examples.x: a horse with a white star on its forehead
a sheriff’s star
I've put a star by the names of the girls in the class.
Liz deserves a gold star for all her hard work.
a four-star general

senses.definition: a mark that represents a star and tells you how good something is, especially a hotel or restaurant

examples.x: three-/four-/five-star hotels
What star rating does this restaurant have?

senses.definition: a famous and excellent singer, performer, sports player, etc.

examples.x: pop/rock/Hollywood/TV stars
a football/tennis/sports star
She acts well but she hasn't got star quality.
Get used to her face as she is a rising star.
She's a former child star.
He's so good—I'm sure he'll be a big star.
The best models receive star treatment.

senses.definition: a person who has the main part, or one of the main parts, in a film, play, etc.

examples.x: The star of the show was a young Italian singer.
The show has plenty of guest stars appearing each week.
She was the star of many popular television series.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is the best of a group

examples.x: a star student
Paula is the star of the class.
He was the star performer at the championships.
The star prize is a weekend for two in Paris.
The monkey was the star attraction (= the best or most popular act) at the show.
Through high school he was a track star.

senses.definition: used to show that you feel very grateful for something that somebody has done or that you think they are wonderful

examples.x: Thanks! You're a star!

senses.definition: a description of what somebody thinks is going to happen to somebody in the future, based on the position of the stars and planets when they were born

examples.x: Do you read your stars in the paper?

senses.definition: the layer of the earth’s atmosphere between about 10 and 50 kilometres above the surface of the earth
in the layer of the earth's atmosphere between about 10 and 50 kilometres above the surface of the earth

examples.x: stratospheric clouds/ozone

senses.definition: extremely high

examples.x: stratospheric levels of success

senses.definition: the star that shines in the sky during the day and gives the earth heat and light son

examples.x: The sun was shining and birds were singing.
the sun’s rays
The sun rises highest in the sky during the summer.
the rising/setting sun
The sun was just setting.
A pale wintry sun shone through the clouds.
The vampire is killed by the first rays of the morning sun.

senses.definition: the light and heat from the sun

examples.x: the warmth of the afternoon sun
The sun was blazing hot.
This room gets the sun in the mornings.
We sat in the sun.
The harvested crop is dried in the hot Indian sun.
They've booked a holiday in the sun (= in a place where it is warm and the sun shines a lot).
We did our best to keep out of the sun.
Her face had obviously caught the sun (= become red or brown) on holiday.
Too much sun ages the skin.
I was driving westwards and I had the sun in my eyes (= the sun was shining in my eyes).
Patients are advised to avoid sun exposure for six weeks.

senses.definition: any star around which planets move
a stream of light from the sun
the light from the sun

examples.x: a ray/pool of sunlight
shafts of bright sunlight
The morning sunlight flooded into the room.

senses.definition: a ray of light from the sun
the time when the sun first appears in the sky in the morning

examples.x: We got up at sunrise.
We left before sunrise.

senses.definition: the colours in the part of the sky where the sun first appears in the morning

examples.x: the pinks and yellows of the sunrise
They looked out at the silvery yellow of the highland sunrise.

senses.definition: the time when the sun goes down and night begins

examples.x: Every evening at sunset the flag was lowered.

senses.definition: the colours in the part of the sky where the sun slowly goes down in the evening

examples.x: a spectacular sunset

senses.definition: a fixed period of time after which a law or the effect of a law will end

examples.x: There is a five-year sunset on the new tax.

senses.definition: the time when the sun rises and day begins
the moment at which an aircraft leaves the ground and starts to fly

examples.x: The plane is ready for take-off.
take-off speed
Owing to the fog, there were no take-offs from the airport yesterday.
The local economy is poised for take-off.

senses.definition: the moment when your feet leave the ground when you jump
if you do a take-off of somebody, you copy the way they speak or behave, in a humorous way to entertain people take-off
to leave the ground and begin to fly

examples.x: The plane took off an hour late.

senses.definition: to leave a place, especially in a hurry

examples.x: When he saw me coming he took off in the opposite direction.

senses.definition: to become successful or popular very quickly or suddenly

examples.x: The new magazine has really taken off.
Her singing career took off after her TV appearance.

senses.definition: a piece of equipment like a tube in shape, containing lenses, that you look through to make objects that are far away appear larger and nearer

examples.x: to look at the stars through a telescope

senses.definition: the region of the atmosphere above the mesosphere
the lowest layer of the earth’s atmosphere, between the surface of the earth and about 6–10 kilometres above the surface sphere
the small amount of light or the period of time at the end of the day after the sun has gone down

examples.x: It was hard to see him clearly in the twilight.
We went for a walk along the beach at twilight.

senses.definition: the final stage of something when it becomes weaker or less important than it was

examples.x: She was in the twilight of her career by then.
He spent his twilight years (= the last years of his life) living with his daughter in Bristol.

senses.definition: a strange object that some people claim to have seen in the sky and believe is a spacecraft from another planet (the abbreviation for ‘unidentified flying object’) UFO
the whole of space and everything in it, including the earth, the planets and the stars

examples.x: Could there be intelligent life elsewhere in the universe?
theories of how the universe began
As far as we know, the entire universe was created in the big bang.

senses.definition: a system of stars, planets, etc. in space outside our own

examples.x: The idea of a parallel universe is hard to grasp.
He lives in a little universe of his own.
A tidal pool is its own little universe, bustling with activity and life.

senses.definition: a particular area of experience or activity

examples.x: the moral universe

senses.definition: the planet in the solar system that is 7th in order of distance from the sun
the planet in the solar system that is second in order of distance from the sun, between Mercury and the Earth
a long journey, especially by sea or in space

examples.x: an around-the-world voyage
a voyage in space
The Titanic sank on its maiden voyage (= first journey).
Going to college can be a voyage of self-discovery.
Darwin’s epic voyage of exploration

senses.definition: to become gradually weaker or less important

examples.x: Her enthusiasm for the whole idea was waning rapidly.
Their popularity waned during that period.
Demand for the product shows no signs of waning.

senses.definition: to appear slightly smaller each day after being round and full
to polish something with wax
to cover something with wax

examples.x: waxed paper
a waxed jacket

senses.definition: to remove hair from a part of the body using wax

examples.x: to wax your legs/to have your legs waxed

senses.definition: to seem to get gradually bigger until its full form can be seen
to become lyrical, etc. when speaking or writing

examples.x: He waxed lyrical on the food at the new restaurant.
He waxed eloquent about her talents as an actor.

senses.definition: having no weight or appearing to have no weight, for example because there is no gravity

examples.x: Astronauts work in weightless conditions.

senses.definition: the fact of having or appearing to have no weight, for example because there is no gravity

examples.x: an experience of weightlessness

senses.definition: a small star that is near the end of its life and is very dense (= solid and heavy)
a hole made by a worm or young insect
a possible connection between regions of space-time that are far apart
the highest point that the sun or moon reaches in the sky, directly above you

examples.x: The sun rose towards its zenith.

senses.definition: the time when something is strongest and most successful

examples.x: The rock band was at the zenith of its creative powers.

senses.definition: the imaginary area in the sky in which the sun, moon and planets appear to lie, and which has been divided into twelve equal parts, each with a special name and symbol

examples.x: the signs of the zodiac

senses.definition: a diagram of these twelve parts, and signs that some people believe can be used to predict how the planets will influence our lives
